Message.Msg: Local Corporation’s Krillion® Platform Powers Shopping Channel for Pittsburgh Post-Gazette IRVINE, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- Local Corporation (NASDAQ: LOCM), a leading online local media company, today announced that it is powering a new local shopping channel for the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette through its online property. . Other well-known of the more than 1,600 members in the Network of Local Corp: The Gazette The Record Searchlight The State Journal-Register The Telegraph Treasure Coast Triangle411 Valley News Ventura County Star Vermont Today Washington Post Journal Star Knoxville News Sentinel LaCrosse Tribune NC Times Newsday Norwich Bulletin Observer-Reporter Orange County Register Pittsburgh Post-Gazette San Diego Union Tribune Santa Ynez Valley News Savannah Morning News St. Louis Post-Dispatch Star Banner The Arizona Republic The Augusta Chronicle The Commercial Appeal The Dispatch The Examiner The Florida Times Union Arizona Daily Star Arkansas News Boston Herald Columbia Daily Herald Cumberland Times News Daily Herald - Utah Daily Princetonian Daily Tarheel East Valley Tribune Honolulu Star Advertiser

Message.Msg: IP & Technology of Local Corp 07:47 #5769 Proprietary platform and know-how - Real time business, product and services data integration - Large scale local/commercial content production and syndication - Very large scale CPC ad-serving and distribution - Web indexing and local search relevance - Very large scale SEO, SEM campaign expertise - Local display ad production and syndication - Web hosting and local/commercial domain name acquisition 12 patents issued, 7 pending Key patents - Local web indexing (for indexing local web sites across the web) - Pay per call for local and commercial searches via a mobile device (multiple patents) The billion dollar industry question: How do we monetize mobile? - Dynamic cascading menu search (for product search on tablets and smart phones) - Bulk domain registration Source: CORPORATE OVERVIEW | 3Q2013

Message.Title: Company deceptively attributes margin "gains" to services but 75% of sales gains came from Gen Merch and Elc Products
Message.Msg: Total sales rose 3286 while a simple review of the 10Q reveals media product sales fell from $2988 to $2760 mils QOQ.Media services rose from 1612 to 2273 ,almost ALL in North Americas (none I'ntl) Electronics and gen'l merch from 8558 to 11048, or 2490 of the 3286 gain, yet with this sales gain income falls flat. All AWS and credit card sales gain of a measly 352 mil came in North America All cash gains come from an increase in payables. If the company "re-invested" profits back into technology etc, they would report net income and an increase in assets on the bal. sheet. They dont b/c the expense is actually a one time cost of doing business and the losses are real. They will never make money no matter how large the sales grow. You can sell alot of merchandise at losses and ship it for nearly free to prime members. Thats why they lose one billion or so quarter on net shipping. One day investors will wake up and say, Hey! Who knew? The answer: Everyone who actually knows how to read a 10Q.clearly not the WS analyst shilld. And never Cramer et al.

Topic.Title: Company deceptively attributes margin "gains" to services but 75% of sales gains came from Gen Merch and Elc Products

Message.Msg: “They dont b/c the expense is actually a one time cost of doing business and the losses are real.” No, the levels of depreciation vary and are a smaller percentage during expansion phases than otherwise. They’re also amortized in many cases at faster rate than with most companies so it never works out that all more even that much of it is “actually a one time cost of doing business”. You simply have not analyzed the ten year cycle appropriately. If you had I don't think you would have ever tried shorting the stock.

Topic.Title: Company deceptively attributes margin "gains" to services but 75% of sales gains came from Gen Merch and Elc Products

Message.Msg: LOL. You prove my point. The faster you amortize or depreciate a CAPEX "investment" you are just proving that it is NOT a long term re-investment of capital but merely a one time cost of doing business. Nothing in scalability will enhance profits and that has been PROVEN already quarter after quarter as revenues rise and net profits do not, but losses are consistent. One thing is assured.All those who believe in the "story" will wake up one day at 265 and say, "what a great buying opportunity" when in fact it will be the beginning of the end. Walmart shows gross margins of 25 % for decades and net profits after SGA etc of 6%. And that is on sales of 450 Billion. It sells at a p/s of .5. Amazon could potentially be afforded that valuation even if they cannot get a bottom line profit so at 200 billion in sales it could be worth 100 Billion.But then again, after dilution of ISOs etc, that would be just about 200 a share. I think 200 is aggressively overvaluing this, but time will tell when real sellers attempt to liquidate in a real bear market. Your analysis is pathetic.

Topic.Title: Amazon retail is a non-value added middleman

Message.Msg: It's not double-talk. Losing money now and losing money in the future is bad. A long believes they are investing now for bigger "future profit". If HDX fails, then it's not going to be that future profit realized. Cutting loses on a loser initiative and investing in something that will make money "could" work. In amazon's case, they are priced like a super tech giant, but they are no match for the superior competition. Kindle Fire is blackberry. A realized failure of Kindle Fire is the end of the road for revenue growth and the fantasy of future profits. To even stay in business, they need to be investing in winners. None of their off-shoots are winners and the core commodity retail middleman business will never realize the fantasy future profits either. This house of cards is built on revenue growth rates that aren't going to sustained and fantasy hypothetical future profits. HDX failure is one pin that can pop this bubble.

Message.Title: So the new story is- AMZN will never show profits
Message.Msg: They will just put profits in to new businesses until they have every business cornered. From forbes: "The way to think of Amazon here is not as “a business” but as ” a series of businesses”. It just happens that the growth to profitability of each of these businesses and then the recycling of those profits into further new projects is happening inside the boundaries of one firm. Rather than, say, through a series of firms." Please do note that this is an analogy, it’s not a precise and exact guide to what is going on. But with this mental image we can then answer the question of whether there is a switch that can be flipped and Amazon starts making profits? Sure there is. And no, it’s not the bankruptcy of all other retail businesses so that Amazon can raise prices. Instead it’s simply that Amazon could stop investing in those new businesses and the profits it is already making from the mature ones would become apparent. Maybe the shareholders would like that to happen some day and maybe Bezos would or would not. But that’s all that has to happen for Amazon to start showing good profits. Just stop investing the ones it is already making in new lines of business."

Message.Title: 5 Disruptive Effects on Q4 Revenue
Message.Msg: 1) Obamacare stole Christmas: The meat and potatoes (middle class) of the economy are getting pre-holiday sticker shock from their insurance situation. That's thousands of dollars each family. 2) 5% Food Stamps Reduction: EBT cards for 50M Amricans get an accross the board hit on Nov 1st. Although it's justified because of the massive fraud and federal budget constraints, it's also less "play" money for the foodstampers to use on their iPhones and such 3) Best Buy is Back in the game: For many years, Amazon benefited from vampiric sales from Best Buy. This season is different thanks largely to California sales tax (and other big states) new cost this year for online orders. Many pricey and easy to ship electronics will be had locally with a boom for BB. No more $50 sales tax advantage on that $500 item in California. 4) Walmart is the #2 largest ecommerce retailer (OK, it's a tie for #2, but not for long and up from 4th place this year passing Apple and now passing Staples): Amazon has had good growth for ecommerce, but there's one company with a bigger growth rate now than Amazon. #2 ecommerce retailer Walmart has only one thing in its sights.... guess who? 5) Kindle Fire HDX wimper - Unsold Units is ungained revenue. How much farther below cost to unload them? Kindle is blackberry and this is a big problem when planned growth doesn't pan out. How big will the loss be? Who cares right? Well, this is all disruption to revenue!

Topic.Title: 5 Disruptive Effects on Q4 Revenue

Message.Msg: All those 5 items are guaranteed, but the risk is even worse to the downside... 1) Fed Taper "could" start, but not expected, but why is a $15B taper so feared? It's out there as a wildcard to start Q4. Pressure on Yellen's nomination might scrutinize why they don't try a taper. 2) Recession may start. We're on the edge. An acknowledgement of a coming recession may be unavoidable, so that would be another wildcard inter-twined 3) Effects of Obamacare might be more than just middleclass getting sticker shock. We're in the throws of upheaval on 16.7% of the eceonomy too 4) Iran is only "weeks" away they say. Is something going to happen or not?? 5) Disfunctional negotiations will continue in Washington right through Q4. They'll talk increased taxes and maybe an internet tax too all through Q4. It'll be crazy. So, there are plenty of additional wildcard Q4 downside risks that are heating up possible. Will these be disruptive to amazon's revenue growth? Yes. Who wants to buy or hold into a quarter that is going down?! The gig is up.

Topic.Title: So the new story is- AMZN will never show profits

Message.Msg: Irrational Exuberance is showing it's ugly head again - 13 years after the first round. This time, AMZN is fooling investors in by building up volume and undercutting all peers by charging less for services and goods. If China was doing this they would be prosecuted under the anti-dumping rules. But AMZN can cleverly use this model and build up their gross income while losing money. How long can they keep this up without investors running out of patience? It's akin to a bubble gum being blown bigger and bigger - we're not sure when but at some point the bubble will burst with a big bang. Investors beware.
